scenario.presenting_complaint:
Reason for Visit

Follow-up after being diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 3 months ago.
scenario.examination_findings:
Background/History

Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 3 months ago.
Past medical history: hypertension (diagnosed 5 years ago), hyperlipidemia.
Medications: Metformin 500 mg twice daily, Lisinopril 10 mg daily, Atorvastatin 20 mg nightly.

Allergies: None reported.
Lifestyle: Sedentary occupation, reports difficulty exercising regularly. Diet high in carbohydrates and sugar.

Subjective (Patient Complaints / Symptoms)
Occasional fatigue.
Increased thirst and urination over past 2 weeks.
Reports difficulty adhering to diet plan.
No chest pain, shortness of breath, or dizziness reported.

Objective (Observations / Measurements)

Weight: 88 kg; Height: 165 cm; BMI: 32 kg/m² (obese).
Blood pressure: 138/85 mmHg.
Recent HbA1c: 8.2% (elevated).
Fasting blood glucose: 9.8 mmol/L (high).
No signs of foot ulcers or infection observed.

Assessment
Poorly controlled type 2 diabetes.
Obesity and sedentary lifestyle contributing to hyperglycemia.
Risk factors: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, overweight.

Plan / Recommendations
Reinforce lifestyle modifications: low-sugar, high-fiber diet, and regular physical activity (e.g., 30 minutes walking, 5 times per week).
Review adherence to Metformin; consider dose adjustment if glycemic control remains poor.
Schedule referral to a dietitian for personalized meal planning.
Monitor blood glucose at home at least twice daily and keep a log.
Follow-up appointment in 6 weeks to review blood glucose, HbA1c, and adherence to lifestyle plan.
Educate patient on warning signs of hyperglycemia and when to seek medical advice.
scenario.task_instructions:
OET Writing Task – Instructions
Task Type:

Letter (Referral, Discharge, or Transfer)

Time:

45 minutes
Word Limit:
180–200 words

Scenario:

You are a healthcare professional (nurse, doctor, or allied health) working in a hospital or clinic. You have been asked to write a letter regarding a patient’s care. The letter may be:
Referral to another healthcare professional
Discharge summary for follow-up
Transfer to another department or facility

You Will Be Given:
Patient details (name, age, gender)
Reason for referral or visit
Background / medical history
Current symptoms or complaints
Observations / vital signs / test results
Treatment / medications
Recommendations or plan

Your Task:
Write a formal, professional letter to another healthcare professional.
Include the following sections:
Recipient and greeting (e.g., “Dear Dr. Smith,”)
Patient details (brief summary)
Reason for referral / follow-up / transfer
Relevant background and current condition
Treatment or interventions to date
Recommendations / plan / follow-up
Closing and signature

Tips for Success:
Use professional, clear, and concise language.
Avoid including unnecessary details.
Check grammar, punctuation, and spelling.
Make sure the letter is logical and easy to follow.
Use medical terminology accurately, but keep it appropriate for the recipient.Write a referral letter based on the case notes above.
